comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:EMBREY, CYRIL STUART
Initials:C S
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Second Lieutenant
Regiment/Service:South Staffordshire Regiment
Unit Text:1st/6th Bn.
Age:20
Date of Death:12/10/1918
Awards:M C, Twice Mentioned in Despatches
Additional information:Son of Mr. H. P. and Mrs. M. Embrey, of Rough Close, Stoke-on-Trent.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:A. 17.
Cemetery:FRESNOY-LE-GRAND COMMUNAL CEMETERY EXTENSION

comment.author: 69717788@N04
comment._content: Monumental Inscriptions at Auchencairn Cemetery In glorious and most loving memory of Cyril Stuart Embrey, 2nd Lieut., South Staffordshire Regiment, killed in action in the Great War, 12th Oct. 1918, aged 20 years. He was awarded the Military Cross and was twice mentioned in dispatches for exceptional bravery in face of great difficulties. History records the exploits of his regiment. He engaged in battles which successfully broke through the Hindenburg Line, St. Quentin Canal etc. etc. and after having witnessed the final route of the German army he was killed by secreted machine gun. His body lies in the Bristol Cemetery of Fresnoy-le-Grand, France www.kirkyards.co.uk/rerrick/auchencairn.asp?offset=140 Entry in London Gazette: 2nd Lt. Cyril Stuart Embrey, S. Staff. R. For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty when on patrol'. He located an enemy post consisting of one officer and seven men. With a party of five he rushed the post, captured two prisoners and killed one of the enemy. The remainder ran away. He displayed great initiative,coolness and dash. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30950/supplements/12071/p...
